The PSM elements are implemented to satisfy the PSM requirements and are discussed here for completeness only since St. Lawrence qualifies as a program level 1 RMP process.

Employee Participation:
Employee participation is the foundation block to an evergreen and integrated PSM program.  WTG's PSM program is heavily focused on this key element.  The new employees of the St. Lawrence Gas Plant have been involved during construction and now into startup and have been actively involved in the implementation of each element of PSM for this new site.  WTG incorporates employee participation in all elements of PSM and other areas of safety.


Process Safety Information:
Comprehensive reviews of the available process safety information (PSI) have been conducted.  All PSI such as maximum intended inventory (MII), design piping and instrumentation diagrams (P&IDs), construction codes and standards used, relief valve study, cause and effect chart, safe upper and lower operating limits, and heat and material balances have been completed.  A comprehensive electronic web-based system utilized for timely access to information has made this data available to all personnel involved with operating the process.

Accidental Release Prevention Policy:
Protecting and responsibly managing natural resources demonstrates stewardship and is critical to the quality of life in the communities we serve, to the environment, and to WTG South Permian Midstream LLC (WTG's) long-term business success.  Promoting the health and safety of co-workers, contractors, customers, and communities is the responsibility of all WTG employees.  WTG will meet all applicable laws, rules, and regulations.

Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled:
St. Lawrence Gas Plant (St. Lawrence), is in Garden City, Glasscock County, Texas.  St. Lawrence is a new natural gas liquids recovery plant that will produce pipeline specification natural gas and natural gas liquids (NGL, also known as Y-grade) from high pressure natural gas collected throughout the upstream gathering system.  St. Lawrence will treat and process flammable gas and liquid mixtures in an amount greater than the threshold quantity containing any of the following RMP-regulated constituents:
¿	Methane
¿	Ethane
¿	Propane
¿	Isobutane
¿	Butane
¿	Isopentane
¿	Pentane
The only RMP-regulated toxic constituent present at St. Lawrence, which is part of the amine treating process, is hydrogen sulfide; however, quantities at this facility are well below the threshold quantity.  St. Lawrence is scheduled for initial startup during August/September of 2020.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:
WTG is committed to ensuring a safe work environment for all its employees, contractors, and vendors.  The St. Lawrence Gas Plant has a detailed Emergency Response Plan and will be coordinating with the community's local responders to introduce them to the new gas plant.  Mock emergency simulations will be conducted before startup and then after site operations are consistent and stable.

Operating Procedures:
Written operating procedures that reference PSI are available.  These procedures are organized by major process areas (such as amine system, glycol system, refrigeration system, stabilization system, utilities, among others) and address initial startup, normal operation, startups, shutdowns, emergency operation, and temporary operation of the facility.  WTG has published operating procedures to the company's electronic web-based system (COMEPLI).

Management of Change (MOC) and Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR):
Improvements to the company's MOC procedure and associated checklists are in progress to ensure a comprehensive and easily usable program are available for all sites to use.  The MOC program will be in effect at St. Lawrence once the gas plant begins operations.  

A new and extensive company PSSR procedure and checklists for applicable disciplines (electrical, instrumentation, procedures, etc.) have been developed and implemented.  This updated procedure and checklists have been used to conduct the PSSRs for the new St. Lawrence Gas Plant prior to start of the facility.  The new procedure and checklists are available on the company's web-based process library program (COMEPLI).   

Mechanical Integrity (MI):				
St. Lawrence has been designed per applicable construction code requirements, including American Petroleum Institute, American Society of Mechanical Engineers, and American Society of Testing Materials.  The company's mechanical integrity program will be implemented within the first year of this site's operation.

Universal Prevention Activities
The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to the RMP-covered process at St. Lawrence.  Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors.

Specialized Safety Features:

The St. Lawrence Gas Plant has safety features on many units to help:
I.	contain/control a release
II.	quickly detect a release; and
III.	reduce the consequences of (mitigate) a release.
Release Detection
I.	Hydrocarbon detectors with alarms located throughout the process along with automatic shutoff of natural gas compressors
II.	Fire eyes located on each compressor and connected to the automatic shutoff of the compressors 
III.	Remote emergency shutdown for all inlet gas, outlet products and fuel pipeline valves.  Along with the shutdown and isolation of the entire gas plant process.
IV.	Hydrogen sulfide detectors with alarms located in designated process areas
V.	Routine operator rounds/equipment inspections
VI.	Operators are on-site continually (8,760 hours per year)

Release containment/control measures include:
I.	Main process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases
II.	Automated and manual valves to permit isolation of the process
III.	Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high temperature)
IV.	Curbing to contain liquid releases
V.	Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system)
VI.	Atmospheric relief devices

Release mitigation measures include:
I.	Fire extinguishing systems
II.	Personnel trained in emergency action
III.	Personal protective equipment (e.g., chemical protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus)

A mix of qualified personnel are involved in the root cause analysis investigations to ensure root cause is consistently identified.  A process safety tracking tool is in use to track action items and incident investigation corrective actions to closure.  

Compliance Audits:
To meet compliance with PSM/RMP, WTG conducts compliance audits every three years to verify all PSM/RMP element requirements are being satisfied.  In WTG's general PSM/RMP improvement program initiatives, an updated audit protocol has been established and implemented within WTG.  As St. Lawrence is a new facility, the first compliance audit will be performed no later than August/September 2023.

Hot Work Permit:
The company's hot work procedure and permit will be used and maintained on file after St. Lawrence begins operating.  Throughout the PSM program assessment process, hot work procedures will be reviewed and updated as necessary.

Contractors
WTG has a comprehensive web-based electronic program for contractors that includes review of all their required records.  A review of the contractor's safety record both prior to selection and during their time of employment is being developed.

Training:
St. Lawrence operators have all completed certification training prior to startup of the facility.  The operators were trained in process systems, including chemical and physical hazards and safety systems; plant equipment and operation; safe work practices; operating procedures; and operator duties.  Operators were tested via written and verbal means to demonstrate each operator's understanding of the training material.
